You still hear stories, even three decades later, about the federal government officials and the DEA sweeping through like a broom, trying to clean the streets. The people, they don't forget. Stories are still passed from generation to generation, on through to transplants like me, of those days. The people work hard, even though it's still considered one of the rougher 'hoods' in the entire city, to keep it cleaned up. They still care about what goes on in their city, on their block. They say that if you're white, you shouldn't walk around the Hill after dark. Truly, I believe that this warning is reminiscent of the old days, and it is tinged with the sour taste of social conditioning. Perhaps it is that I am just dark enough to pass for a not entirely "white-girl," or maybe Hilltop recognizes me as one of their own, someone who is just as painfully aware of the reminders that constantly plague our nation. Reminders that racism, cultural conditioning, and assumptions are made out of ignorance and fear, even in a city that is supposed to be a cultural melting pot Utopia. I know one thing: no matter how far I roam, the Hilltop is home. I feel alive walking those streets at night, meeting people who have more quickly and rarely nefariously offered me a jacket than to rob me. It's a place where laundromat owners have stayed open just a few minutes later so I could charge my phone when I had no where to escape from the rain. It's a place where I have sat, believe myself to be invisible, huddled against concrete store fronts on the most grey dreary of nights, only to have someone stop and look me in the eye, hand me a $5, and tell me I'm beautiful and valuable.
I live in Rural America, specifically small town Michigan. Where you go from farmland to small tourist cities. There is no big city malls, no Wal-mart, Target, or even an Applebee’s. Anywhere you need to go, you have to drive to get to. Despite that I live in one of the most beautiful places in the world surrounded by water. My “city” is surrounded by water. Beautiful Lake Michigan to one side, and Lake Charlevoix on the other. Everywhere you go you can find a beach to dip your toes in. My neighborhood, reflects the idea of small town. Houses are not stacked upon one another. They aren’t cookie cutter houses that are built the same. They are older homes, some of them being updated and remodeled some of them being older. Most homes have basements. Full Basements that you can see from the road. Many houses in the neighborhood have older aluminum siding. We have houses every color you can imagine in the blocks that surround my house. Most of the houses have yards. Yards with trampolines, and playsets. Some people have gardens, and fences for their animals. The houses resemble Middle America. Hard working people who work to make a living and are either raising families or have raised families. On any given day you will see kids running up and down the streets. You will also see people walking dogs, biking and rollerblading. Neighbors know neighbors and you can recognize who fits in and who doesn’t belong. You will see someone grilling outside and wave, or even someone that is walking their dog from a few blocks down and smile pleasantly. The lawns are kept in decent condition. Nobody has leaves piled up from fall time. Green grass is kept mowed and under control. If people have plants and bushes in their yards they are kept trimmed down. It isn’t a beautiful neighborhood that you drive into and think wow look at the nice homes, but one you drive into and think you can tell this would be a good place to raise a family. It’s quiet, peaceful and, and safe. While only average looking, it is exceptional for the fact that it represents what people want in the world, which is a safe place to land at the end of the day. Within walking distance there is the county sheriff’s department and jail. The Health department is just next to that. The city recycling center sits just down the road, and neighbors and residents from around the city utilize the services they provide. We have baseball and softball fields nearby where you can hear the announcers keeping score and calling the names of players. Our small town airport is next to that. You can be playing outside, or even inside and hear the rumbles of small engine planes taking off and landing. You can walk to get ice cream from the local ice cream place, and if you are really into it you can make it downtown from our neighborhood of homes. My kids can ride their bikes to the park which is only 8 blocks or so away. It is a really great place to live.
transformed_texts:
The city pressed in, a tangled knot of brick and glass and asphalt. Streets bled into each other, a labyrinth of commerce and concrete. Shops, their windows dark and vacant, stood shoulder to shoulder, silent sentinels to a trade long gone cold. Restaurants, their neon signs flickered weakly, promising meals that were never served. Above it all, a sky choked with smoke, the sun a pale ghost behind the haze.

In this urban wasteland, pockets of humanity clung to existence. Here, a cluster of buildings, their facades chipped and faded, bore witness to a past life of laughter and light. There, a street corner, a makeshift memorial to forgotten dreams, littered with broken glass and discarded hopes.  

And then, amidst the decay, a flicker of humanity. A child, his eyes wide with a wonder that belied the desolation around him, pointed to a crumbling storefront. "Papa," he whispered, "look, a store." The man looked at him, a shadow of a smile playing on his lips. "Yes, son," he said, his voice rough as gravel. "A store."

They walked on, their footsteps echoing on the empty streets. The air hung heavy with the scent of dust and decay, a testament to a city that had lost its heart.  But in the boy's eyes, a spark of hope remained. He saw not the desolation, but the possibilities. He saw the ghosts of families who had gathered around tables, of children who had played in the streets, of lives that had once pulsed with energy. 

They passed a park, its swings swaying listlessly in the wind. A playground, its slides and monkey bars rusted and silent. The remnants of laughter, like echoes in the wind, whispered of happier times. The man stopped, his gaze fixed on the empty swings. "Remember," he said, his voice a low rumble. "Even in the darkness, there is always light."

The boy reached out, his hand tracing the cold metal of a swing. "I see it, Papa," he whispered. "I see it."

The houses here, they huddle close, most of them one-story, two-room affairs. A few, split down the middle, sharing a wall but not a soul. My own sits back from the street, a patch of dirt and broken concrete for a yard, a drive that barely fits a car. It's a picture of a time just faded, the American dream, they called it, or maybe it was the American ghost. Now it's a whisper on the wind. A faded photograph. 

The folks here, they hold on tight, though. You can see it in the way they keep their lawns mowed, though the blades are dulled, the edges ragged. You see it in the way the kids, they still run through the streets, ignoring the cars, ignoring the world beyond this little patch of dust and asphalt. The schoolhouse stands, a brick monument to a time when futures were bright. Ninety years old, it is, filled to the brim with a hundred dreams. The churches, though, they're mostly empty now. But the basketball courts, they're packed every night.

A supermarket, Super "A" they call it, owned by a Yemeni family, the only ones I know of. The rest, mostly Black, their families woven through the years like roots in the earth. The streets are wide, the air thick with the scent of barbeque and exhaust. Football in the street, a game played with old, worn-out shoes and dreams stitched into their seams. 

The old karate school is gone now, replaced by a pharmacy. Hollywood moved on, and so did the kids. They want their fixes now, quick and easy. The movie theater, though, it clings on, showing old films at half-price.  A refuge for the old folks, a place where the world still moves at a slower pace.

There's a highway, a ribbon of concrete that slices through the town next door. We tried to get an exit, but the elders, they said it would ruin things. Keep the world out, they said. Keep it pure. So we're left with the dust and the dreams, waiting for the day when the highway might reach us, or maybe, just maybe, the dreams will reach us first.

The place might slip by you, easy as a shadow. Tucked behind the strip mall, past the shell of that old Whole Foods, past the hotels that only stir to life for summer reunions. A hollowed-out place, but not empty. Not by a long shot.   

If you pushed past the shadow of the abandoned grocery, past the empty eyes of the motels, you’d find a different kind of living. Apartments huddled together, a row of them, like worn-down dolls, their insides spilled out, laid bare. The first ones, they’re known for things best left unsung. But the ones next door, the next two after that… those are a story for a different night.

Across the way, a college tries to keep a quiet vigil. A sleepy campus with students shuffling in, coffee mugs in hand, yawning at dawn. The iron gates creak open, letting them in one by one, while cars honk and impatient drivers curse the slow-turning wheels of the world. The road splits, one way a residential street, the other a park and a place where broken things are mended.

The rehabilitation center, it’s got a porch with chairs that invite you to sit, a ceiling fan that sighs in the summer heat. Kids run in the park, a riot of limbs and laughter, chasing bees amongst the flowers. Old folks walk their dogs, scowling at the teenagers on skateboards, nodding at the girls huddled by the playground, secrets whispered like promises.

A sushi place, a swimming pool store, a nail salon, all crammed together like old friends. You could get your fill of life, all at once. Frozen yogurt, sticky and cold, with toppings piled high, eaten while teenagers show off their tricks on their skateboards, the air thick with the scent of rebellion.

This place, it’s a slice of life, a quiet corner where time slows its pace. An echo of something older, something simpler.

The girl, her eyes wide, looked out at the endless rows of corn. "Where is everything?" she asked, her voice thin in the silence of the car.

"This is it," I said, knowing she hadn't seen a field this vast, this empty.  She was a city girl, her world contained within the walk to the grocery store. This landscape, it spoke of a different kind of life, a life I knew. I told her of growing up here, of the quiet that settled on the land as the sun dipped low, of the way the air tasted after a rain. In that moment, she saw me, not the man she'd met in the city, but the boy who'd chased fireflies in these fields, who'd climbed the trees that stood sentinel over the endless rows.

We passed a quarry, water dark and still, a scar on the land. Beyond it, the houses, brick and stucco, each with its acre of lawn. And the cars. Mercedes, gleaming in the sun, a silent parade of affluence.  A Korean man, his face creased with a lifetime of smiles, pushed his mower, a John Deere green against the backdrop of manicured lawns. He sang a song I didn't know, his voice thin and sweet, his presence a beacon of quiet joy. His laughter, carried on the wind, was a reminder that even in this order, there was room for wildness.

My house, grey stucco and weathered wood, sat at the end of the drive.  Geese honked in the side yard, chased by the terrier. A stream trickled behind the house, a tiny thread of life in the vastness. Bullfrogs croaked their evening song, and in the distance, a cow mooed, a lonely sound in the stillness.

A wooden bridge spanned the stream, leading to a small clearing. Here, beneath the trees, was my sanctuary. I built forts, chased rabbits, dreamt dreams as big as the sky.  It was here I spent my childhood, a world away from the city girl's reality.

Winter, she said, her voice full of wonder.  I told her of the snow, the quiet, the way the world shrunk to the size of the backyard. Of snow forts and snowball fights, of laughter echoing in the crisp air. We built snowmen, our hands clumsy and cold, and made snow angels with wings as wide as the sky.

"It was a different time," I said, my voice catching. "A time when everything else didn't matter."  She looked at me, her eyes reflecting the setting sun, and for a moment, I saw a flicker of understanding. She saw the boy in the man, the place where the wildness still stirred.

The air hung heavy, thick with the smell of rain and pine.  Portland. It clung to you, that word.  Like the fog that settled over the Willamette, a shroud over the city's soul. They called it "weird," this town. A claim tattooed on the side of a building that somehow served as a pizza joint, a bar, a stage for ghosts, and a place where the shadows danced with sin. Keep Portland Weird, the sign rasped. A faded promise, a hollow echo of a time before the gold rush, before the Californians came with their money and their manicured lawns, before the city swallowed its own heart.

Some claimed it was a celebration, a rallying cry for the misfits, the dreamers, the artists who carved their souls into the city's weathered bones. Others saw it as a warning, a desperate plea to hold onto something, anything, in the face of change.  But change, like the rain, was inevitable.  It seeped into the cracks, eroded the edges, left its mark on everything it touched.

Portland was a paradox, a symphony of contradictions.  Yoga studios nestled beside thrift stores overflowing with forgotten dreams.  Hipsters with their ironic mustaches sipped lattes while businessmen in pressed suits hurried by, their eyes fixed on their phones.  The city pulsed with a nervous energy, a frenetic rhythm that masked a deep, underlying melancholy.

And then there were the boxes.  The free boxes that lined the sidewalks like fallen angels, their cardboard wings outstretched, offering a glimpse into someone else's discarded life.  A tattered sweater, a worn-out book, a chipped teacup - each object a whisper of a story, a fragment of a forgotten past.  The city, in its own strange way, was trying to connect, to share its burdens, its secrets, its dreams.

It was a place where you could be anything you wanted to be, but only as long as you accepted the darkness that lurked beneath the surface.  A place where hope and despair danced a delicate waltz, where the line between sanity and madness was blurred by the perpetual drizzle.  Portland was a city that wore its scars like badges of honor, a testament to the resilience of the human spirit, a reminder that even in the midst of chaos, beauty could be found.

The mountains. They were always there. Like a dark watch in the north, they saw the sun rise and fall, day after day. Didn't matter how hard I tried to forget them, how lost I got in the grit of the world, they were still there. Solid. Unmoving. Unconcerned with the noise of things. But there were days when the wind caught in my bones, when the world felt too tight, and they called to me. I'd turn my face to them, and the mountains wouldn't judge. They'd just be there, a silent strength against the ache in my chest. It started when I came here, to this college town. The mountains north of campus, they were the first thing that caught my eye. 

The university, it had its own kind of beauty. Buildings, ponds, trees whispering secrets in the wind. But it was the mountains that held the real power. This town, it had its own heart too. Downtown, with its brick streets worn soft by time, its cafes spilling out laughter and steam. It had the buzz of a city, but just a whisper away, you could be back in quiet suburbia, past the library, the streets lined with houses that seemed to hum with the lives lived inside them. The strange thing was, the two lived together, side by side, like whispers and shouts in the same breath. 

There were memories here, carved into the corners of this town. Late-night walks with friends past the rusty swings in the park, the air still thick with the words of an all-nighter. The rush of the downtown streets, the lights of the fancy movie theater, tickets clutched tight in my hand, courtesy of the university. But there were dark memories too. The ponds, they held those.  Silent witnesses to tears shed at two in the morning, to the weight of questions unanswered in the stillness of the night. I'd watch the turtles and the ducks, their lives unfolding without a care, and wonder about my own place in the grand scheme of things.

I walked past the pond, past the houses, past the park, until I reached the main street. The sun was rising then, painting the sky with streaks of gold and crimson, and as I looked up, I saw them. The mountains. They were further than they seemed, their peaks piercing the hazy sky. They were a reminder, a silent promise. The world might spin, might break, but the mountains would always be there. And somehow, in their stillness, I found a strength. A reason to keep going, one step at a time.

The road to Bensonhurst cuts through a city choked with heat and the rattle of a thousand forgotten dreams. Find it you will, though. The iron veins of the subway run deep, a silver thread whispering through the asphalt veins of the city. Here, amongst the brick and mortar canyons, you'll find a place that breathes a different air.

Bensonhurst. It clings to the shore like barnacles on a hull, a city within a city. A tide of faces, a tapestry woven with voices that speak in tongues both familiar and strange. The air itself carries the scent of spices, a symphony of aromas that drift from the storefronts. Asian faces, a mosaic of origins, line the avenues, their eyes reflecting the secrets of a thousand generations. 

The supermarkets, those temples of commerce, are shrines to the abundance of the East. Their shelves groan under the weight of exotic fruits, their refrigerators hum with the promise of meals both familiar and strange. A symphony of sounds: the clatter of tongs against porcelain, the hiss of woks, the murmur of conversations in tongues you can't quite decipher. 

But Bensonhurst is more than just a tapestry of faces and spices. It's a place where children chase laughter through the streets, where the echoes of basketballs bounce off the concrete court in the park, a green island amidst the urban sprawl. The air hums with the energy of a thousand lives, a million stories waiting to be told.

You'll find kindness here, too, in the eyes of shopkeepers who greet you with a smile, in the shared laughter of neighbors gathered on stoops.  But like any city, Bensonhurst has its shadows. The rumble of engines, the screech of brakes, the late-night whispers on darkened corners – these are the echoes of a city that never sleeps.  Keep your wits about you, your eyes open.

And remember this: in a city of millions, every corner holds a story, every face a secret.  In Bensonhurst, these stories whisper in the wind, etched in the lines on weathered faces, woven into the very fabric of the place.

The hill slopes down from my house, a naked bone of earth.  It's called the workout hill. Joggers come up it, gasping, sweating, though there are no sidewalks on this road. Just the blacktop, cracked and pitted in places, slick with rain. The wires overhead, telephone and electric, hang like frayed nerves, a patchwork of repairs after storms. Rain comes often, tears the branches down, a storm of green and brown against the sky. They hate the trees here, the evergreens, crowding in, blocking the view. So the houses climb up, lean out, glass eyes staring, each one wanting a piece of the water. They say the sunsets are beautiful, the bay ablaze, the sky a bleeding orange. But the clouds hold the sun hostage. Most days the light comes through a veil, gray and damp. Moss grows on everything, a living shroud. My car, left in the driveway for a month, turned green and furry. Three hours to scrub it clean. 

There are few children here. A school down the road, but the people are older, retired, the air thick with the scent of pipe tobacco and regret. Dogs are their company, loose and watchful, sometimes bolder, slipping through open doors, eyes bright and hungry. Rabbits, too, underfoot, plump and fearless. The gardeners curse them, digging up roots, tearing lawns apart. My cats, they hunt them.  The birds, sparrows and hummingbirds, a hawk sometimes, chased away by the raucous crows. Down by the bay, there are a few restaurants, the smell of salt and fish heavy in the air. The beach is a narrow strip of sand, but the rocks are good for throwing. The water flat, the opposite shore a faint smudge in the mist.

The dust kicked up by passing cars hung low in the air, a thin veil over the sun-bleached lawns. The asphalt veins of the two highways that bookended our street pulsed with a constant, low hum, a reminder that the world outside these quiet confines still spun. Most days it was just a murmur, the constant thrum of engines and tires, a background score to the slow, steady rhythm of life here. We were a patchwork of familiar faces, folks who knew their neighbors, who knew the routines and rhythms of this small town. 

The houses stood close, paint chipped, roofs weary under the weight of time.  In the winter, the children were a blur of bundled limbs, sleds screeching down the hill that crowned our street. They came and went like seasons, a fleeting echo of laughter in the crisp air. Grown men wrestled with lawnmowers, their engines sputtering and sighing, a ritual as old as the town itself. The scent of cut grass hung heavy in the air, a sweet, earthy perfume that spoke of summer's slow decay.  

We lived in a house at the corner, a sentinel at the edge of this quiet world. Each face that passed, each car that rolled by, was a story whispered in the wind. We saw it all, the comings and goings, the mundane, the momentous.  Our life revolved around the house, around the steady work that filled our days. My wife and I, our daughters, eleven and fourteen, a tapestry woven from the threads of family and routine. We were anchors, rooted in this place, our lives a slow, steady tide against the relentless push of the world.

Sometimes, rain would fall, a curtain of silver against the tired green of the trees. The children would splash in puddles, their laughter echoing in the empty streets. The air would be thick with the smell of wet earth, a primal scent that spoke of renewal and decay. We'd gather on the back deck, the grill spitting sparks against the darkening sky, the scent of barbecue a comforting beacon in the gathering gloom.

Evenings brought a quiet hush. The children, tucked in their beds, the world outside fading into a distant hum. I'd sit in the garage, tinkering with my truck, the air thick with the smell of oil and gasoline. It was a sanctuary, a place where the world outside seemed to melt away.  

Holidays brought a brief flicker of change, a surge of visitors, a kaleidoscope of unfamiliar faces. The driveway would overflow with cars, the air thick with the scent of pot roast and laughter.  But even then, the quiet would return, a slow, steady pull back into the familiar rhythm. We were a neighborhood bound by routine, by the ebb and flow of everyday life. It wasn't perfect, but it was ours.

The dust. It clung to everything. Houses, cars, skin. A brown canvas stretched to the horizon, broken only by the occasional bleached skeleton of a tree. You see brown out here.  You see it in the sun-bleached grass that clings to life between cracks in the pavement, in the drifts of dust devils that dance across the empty expanse. Even the lawns, the few that dare to defy the aridity, are monuments to stubborn defiance, watered and manicured at a price that speaks of a desperate yearning for something green. 

It wasn’t always this way. When I first came here, in the shadow of the nineties, the houses were scattered, islands in a sea of dust. Now, the sea recedes, swallowed by a tide of new construction. Every day, more brown gives way to gray. The city stretches, a slow wound in the landscape.

The people are mostly good. Kind, worn faces etched with the lines of a hard life. But like any place, there are shadows. Places where the dust settles deeper, whispers of trouble linger. Still, I find myself drawn to their stoic resilience.

The stores are the same everywhere: Food for Less, Smart & Final, chains that stretch across the land like barbed wire fences. For anything else, you have to hunt, to journey further into the wilderness of concrete and asphalt. No Whole Foods here, no haven of organic produce.

Construction. That’s the lifeblood of this place. A city still in its infancy, building, expanding, devouring the landscape. It terrifies me, this endless growth. The wide open spaces, the silence, the stark beauty - it’s all being swallowed up. I left the city once and found solace here. I don’t want to go back.

It’s ironic, then, that my work is in that very industry. Drywall, T-bar, the silent language of construction.  My hands build the cages that contain this sprawl, contributing to the very thing I fear.

But there’s a strange beauty here, too. A starkness that cuts through the noise, a silence that speaks volumes. The animals, they understand it. Lizards sunning themselves on rocks, scorpions scuttling under the porch, coyotes howling at the moon.  They are a constant reminder of the wildness that still flickers beneath the surface.

There are people who come here, drawn to the desert’s stark beauty. They seek solace in the silence, a connection to something ancient and profound. They come for the sunsets, the star-filled skies, the sense of being at the edge of the world. 

We have our attractions, too. The annual county fair, a carnival of lights and laughter, a brief respite from the dusty stillness. The mountains to the north, capped with snow, a reminder that there are places of beauty beyond the desert’s embrace. The museum, a collection of artifacts and stories, a testament to the resilience of the human spirit.

Them dorms. They're my neighborhood now. Walls close in, same as any other. But the folks... they're a different breed. Professors with their wives, kids  running wild, young'uns just finding their way. All sharing the same air, the same ground.  Like a hive, buzzing and shifting. 

We got our houses here, too. Not the kind with lawns and porches, mind you. Apartments, stacked high, crammed shoulder to shoulder.  Some say they hold twenty souls apiece. Then there's the old houses, scattered like forgotten bones, where the alumni hole up. Lonely places, those. And the dorms themselves, rows upon rows of rooms, each holding two souls, sharing the thin walls, the whispered secrets, the dreams.

Folks here... they come from everywhere, from every corner of the earth.  The professors, they hold the wisdom, the weight of years on their shoulders. The young ones, they're hungry, searching.  They haven't figured out what they're looking for yet. But they're looking.

We got our stores, too. Not the kind you find on Main Street, mind you.  More like a life raft, keeping us afloat. Grub to eat, clothes to wear, books to bury ourselves in. And the park. That's our common ground, a patch of green in this concrete jungle. A place to breathe, to forget for a while.

It ain't much, this neighborhood of mine. But it's home. For now.

The years here, ten of them now, they’ve etched a path through this place. I came from Riverdale, left behind the ghosts of laughter and tears, traded the familiar streets for this one. A better life they said. A better school, a cleaner slate. Stockbridge. It wasn’t easy, the first days. A boy weeps for what he leaves behind. But my parents, they saw a future here, a haven from the storm. So we came.

This town, it’s a labyrinth. Houses crowding together, streets winding blind alleys. I learned its secrets slowly, inch by inch. Most faces stayed strangers, shadows passing in the dusk. But some lives brushed against mine, leaving a mark. Mr. Glen, his children, they were a light in the darkness. Dennis too, for a while. They became a family, a bridge across the years.

I remember Mr. Glen’s wedding. A second chance at love, a second chance at joy. The white strap, a symbol of forever, sailed through the air and landed in my hand. A small miracle. The music, the laughter, the warmth of the night. Marsharii, one of his daughters, dancing beside me. Her smile, a flicker of sunlight. I haven’t seen her since. I hope she found her own light.

I’ve explored this town, piece by piece, a map unfolding in my mind. Kason, Curtis, my companions in this strange land. We were young, full of fire and dreams. Video games, laughter, the sweet taste of freedom. The park, a sanctuary. Trees whispering secrets, leaves rustling like old prayers. Sticks from the hardware store, a bokken in hand, practicing the dance of defense. The basketball court, the tennis court, echoes of games long past. Mr. Graves, my father’s friend, a gruff man with a heart of gold, teaching me the art of the volley. The memory of sweat and laughter, a bond forged in the heat of competition.

This town, it’s a tapestry woven with threads of joy, of sorrow, of loss and hope. It’s a place where I learned to navigate the darkness, to find light in the shadows. The best, they say, is yet to come. And I believe it.

The college pressed close, its shadow a familiar weight on the neighborhood.  Apartments rose like tired sentinels, most of them weathered and stoic, their brick faded to the color of old bone.  A few places to eat, cheap and greasy, spilled their neon light onto the cracked asphalt. One bar, newly christened, had swabbed itself with a veneer of class, raising its prices along with its expectations. The rest were worn smooth by the passage of students and the lingering scent of something illicit.  

Most of the faces were young, the pale skin stretched taut over cheekbones, eyes hungry for whatever fleeting pleasure the night might offer.  Or maybe it was just the haze of cheap smoke that hung in the air, thick and clinging. There were others, though, shadows flitting between buildings, faces etched with the lines of a hard-won life. They moved through the labyrinthine alleys, seeking solace in the dim light of a flickering streetlamp.

Children, a scuttling pack of energy, darted through the broken streets, their laughter echoing off the cracked sidewalks. An elementary school loomed nearby, its brick facade whispering stories of forgotten lessons.

The air was heavy with the scent of weed, a persistent fog that clung to the peeling paint and worn carpets. The building management had tried to fight back, hanging air fresheners like desperate pleas for normalcy. It was a futile effort, a thin veil over the truth.

Across the street, a newer complex rose like a monument to misplaced ambition. Its windows glinted with a sterile sheen, its walls painted in shades of artificial optimism. But underneath, the foundations were weak, a testament to the cheapness of haste. The rent, however, was exorbitant, a cruel joke whispered by the wind.

A diner, its neon sign flickering like a dying star, served up meals on paper plates. The food tasted of microwaved despair, but it was cheap, and in this place, that was enough.

The road, once a forgotten scar, had been reshaped by the city's fickle hand. New grass sprouted, a defiant green against the gray concrete. But the sidewalks remained cracked and uneven, a reminder of the city's indifference.

Behind the apartment complex, a wall of trees stood guard, their branches tangled in a silent embrace. They hid the secrets of the street behind, its sidewalks crumbling and its buildings draped in shadows. 

There was a darkness here, a restlessness that clung to the air. Whispers of crime and transience echoed through alleyways, painting a bleak picture of lives fleeting and lost.

But I stayed, drawn to the city's pulse, the constant hum of possibility. I could afford it, and there was a certain grim satisfaction in surviving, in carving out a space in this forgotten corner of the world. The university, a beacon of light, was within walking distance, its books and classrooms offering a temporary escape from the bleakness. The bus stops, like silent sentinels, promised a gateway to the wider world.

For now, this was my home. A place of shadows and secrets, of broken dreams and flickering hope.

The houses huddled close, a row of yellow bricks under a sky the color of bone. Each one a mirror to the next, porch white, roof green as a serpent's eye. They leant into each other, a wall of sameness on the dead end street, a place where time seemed to turn slow, like the molasses of memory. Kids ran barefoot in the dust, their laughter catching on the wind like fireflies. Grown men stood, voices low, spitting tobacco juice into the cracked pavement, their faces creased with stories the sun had etched. It was a world of porch swings and cicadas, of sweet tea and the smell of honeysuckle thick in the air. A world left behind, or perhaps never truly found.

But the wind carried a different kind of song now, a low rumble in the belly of the sky. The air grew thick and heavy, the sky turning the color of old bruises. The warnings came, whispers at first, then a siren's wail that sliced through the peace. Fear, a cold snake, coiled in the pit of her stomach. She gathered her things, a dog in her arms, another whimpering at her heels. The bathroom, the smallest refuge in the face of the storm.

The hail came then, a thousand tiny fists pounding on the roof. The world outside was a whirlwind of white, a sheet of icy rain. When it passed, the road steamed, the air alive with the scent of ozone and wet earth. The sun broke through the clouds, casting a rainbow across the sky, a promise whispered on the wind. 

But the peace was fragile. The world beyond the porch swings was still a place of change, of storms both literal and unseen. She watched the neighborhood stir, the familiar rhythm returning, children laughing, men speaking, life carrying on as if nothing had happened. 

She knew it was just a matter of time before the next storm. But for now, she would savor the quiet, the sense of belonging, the warmth of the sun on her face. This place, this haven, was all she had. This was her world, for now.

The dust settled on the houses, two stories high, like bone bleached by the sun.  Each Sunday, the air filled with the shouts of children, laughter harsh against the silence of the empty days. The houses stood in a row, each identical to the next, a testament to some forgotten uniformity. I moved in during the waning light of adolescence, a boy on the edge of becoming something else, something unknown. 

I found solace in the company of two boys, one two houses down, the other down the street. Their laughter echoed in my memory, though their absence now hung like a shroud. The faces around here, though, they stayed. Faces etched with time and routine, their eyes reflecting the slow burn of a life lived in the same dust-filled streets.

The park, a patch of green in the sea of asphalt, whispered memories. The worn basketball court, the cracked field where we played football until the sun bled out. There, I learned the sting of defeat, the taste of blood on my lips, the sharp ache of a broken nose. But the laughter, the echo of camaraderie, those memories linger, a faint ghost of a time gone by. Now, the park is a playground for younger ones, their squeals a reminder of a life lived in moments, not years.

Food came in a symphony of smells. The air, thick with the scent of spices, carried whispers of distant lands. Chinese, Indian, Mexican, Italian, all within a stone's throw. But the food itself, it seemed, had become a commodity, delivered in sterile boxes, a pale imitation of the experience.

So much like every other place, yet somehow different. The stores lined the streets, a predictable tapestry of convenience and necessity. Dry cleaners, pharmacies, supermarkets, all promising a sense of normalcy.  Even the Indian shop, a haven of unfamiliar aromas, seemed a pale reflection of the vibrant culture it represented.

I find myself grateful, here in this quiet corner of the world. The stories I hear, the horrors whispered on the wind from distant towns, make me acutely aware of the fragile peace that surrounds me. The dust settles, the children laugh, the days bleed into one another. And in this quiet rhythm, I find a strange, unsettling comfort.

The town sat hunched low, a pale thing beneath a sky that bled the color of old bruises. Johnston. They called it the Peach Capital of the World, a crown worn crooked on a brow of dust and sweat. Fields stretched out like a patchwork quilt, rows of peach trees standing sentinel, their branches heavy with the promise of summer's bounty. Cattle grazed in the hollows, their breath misting in the morning chill. Houses, two stories mostly, stood like weathered sentinels, some cloaked in gray shingles, others with metal roofs shimmering under the relentless sun. They huddled behind fences, nestled in back yards where chickens scratched and dogs barked a lonely chorus. 

The town's heart, a single intersection choked by asphalt, pulsed with the hum of a solitary stoplight. Here, flanked by faded storefronts, the day's commerce was conducted: Hong Kong, a testament to the ghosts of journeys past, served up steaming plates of chow mein; Fiesta, a splash of color against the dusty backdrop, offered the solace of tortillas and salsa; Gary's, a constant in a world of flux, served up burgers drenched in grease. A ghost of a pizzeria lingered, its sign a faded memory. Maxwell and Halford Drug, a haven of sweet-smelling remedies and Cherry Coca-Cola, dispensed more than just pills. The Independent Grocers Alliance, a bastion of overpriced staples, stood as a testament to the town's isolation. But it was Dollar General, a beacon of bargain hunters' dreams, that truly ruled the heart of Johnston. Its aisles bustled with the mundane necessities of life, a tableau of human need. 

Possibilities Furniture & More, a haven of worn upholstery and whispered promises, held court next door. Clark's Cuts and Kennels, a symphony of barks and the rustle of kibble, offered a haven for furry companions.  

A doctor's office, a veterinary clinic, a schoolhouse with chipped paint - these were the sentinels of care and education. No parks, no playgrounds, no symphony of laughter echoing through the streets. Just the low hum of a town clinging to its own quiet rhythm. A place where time seemed to move slower, where life unfolded in the slow, steady cadence of the seasons. A place where you could disappear, unnoticed, a whisper in the wind.

The first time the name came to him, it was on a static-laced podcast, some story about vanished souls.  Surprising, he thought. This place, this concrete jungle choked with neon and desperation, going for a thousand a month? A breath of dust in the silence. He'd never heard a whisper of it. Neither had his friends. Maybe it was the struggle. He knew a few who cried themselves to sleep, drowning in the rising tide of rents. Things were tight, always had been. But they'd learned to make do. The smell of bargains, of moth-eaten clothes and dusty toys from the flea market, that was the scent of survival. Your skin took on the odor of it, a faint echo of a life lived on the edge.  Here, on the edge of this city, there were three thrift stores within walking distance.  A pilgrimage, if you started on the far side. Two charity emporiums, a library smelling of paper and forgotten dreams, a rare book shop with hushed whispers of the past, and a curio shop, filled with the ghosts of yesterday. Downtown, a maelstrom of engines and hurried feet. But in those stores, silence reigned. A sanctuary from the clamor. A place to lose a day, a week, a lifetime, if you let it. Every year, more of those places sprang up. Cars and people, an endless tide, washing over the city. They called it progress. An online empire, a monument to consumption, rising from the ashes of something older. It reminded him of New York, a thousand lives intersecting, each a universe unto itself. You could be alone here, a ghost in the machine, and no one would notice. Not like the South, where a friendly nod was a lifeline, a code of unspoken expectations. Here, you were a cipher, a shadow flitting through the city's veins. You could keep your secrets, your pain, your memories, locked away behind a wall of indifference. The city would roll on, indifferent to your solitude. Still, there were sounds in the night. The mournful melody of a piano next door, the off-key harmonies of two singers upstairs. A city symphony of the unheard, the unacknowledged. A strange kind of community. Strangers bound by their loneliness, united by their shared desire for connection. He wasn't sure if he was lucky or damned. He had neighbors, after all. A haphazard family forged in the crucible of urban anonymity. They shared meals, mourned losses, celebrated birthdays. They kept each other alive, these fragile souls, adrift in a sea of concrete and steel.  Maybe, he thought, maybe that was all that mattered.

The land stretched flat and featureless, a canvas of lawns all cut to the same length, each yard a mirrored image of the next.  The houses, wooden boxes with identical siding and identical roofs, stood in neat rows like prisoners in a silent, ordered line.  The air hung heavy with the scent of trimmed hedges and the metallic tang of freshly poured concrete. Every driveway, every walkway, every surface seemed polished and scrubbed clean, as if the earth itself had been forced into submission. 

There was a sameness here, a uniformity that pressed down like a shroud. No irregularity dared to break the pattern. No wild weeds pushed through the cracks, no trees grew tall and free, no child's swing set swayed in the wind. It was a place where order reigned, a monument to control. The houses themselves, though seemingly different, shared the same skeletal bones: two-car garages, identical windows, the occasional dormer peeking out like a tired eye. And at the end of each street, huddled together like a flock of wary birds, stood the mailboxes. No individual kiosks on the lawns, no solitary flags snapping in the breeze.  No, here the mailboxes were clustered, a metallic hive where the anonymity of the neighborhood deepened. 

The community pools shimmers like pale scars on the landscape, guarded by high fences and locked gates. The walking trails, paved with the same hard, unforgiving concrete, snaked through the manicured lawns, offering a semblance of freedom within the confines of the grid. 

The people here were mostly old, their faces etched with the lines of a life lived in the shadow of conformity. Some younger faces lingered, caught between the pull of escape and the inertia of routine. But the air itself seemed to whisper a single, monotonous refrain: "Stay within the lines. Stay within the pattern."  

Out beyond the perimeter of the neighborhood, the city sprawled, a vast beast of concrete and glass. A single mall, a beacon of consumerism, stood sentinel at its edge, promising a brief respite from the suffocating sameness.  But even there, the uniformity persisted.  The stores, the restaurants, the people - all carefully curated, all striving for a faceless perfection.

This was the neighborhood. This was the life. Safe, predictable, devoid of surprises.  But in the silence between the manicured hedges, a whisper of discontent lingered.  A yearning for something more, something real.

The town sits low, choked by a fog of dust that settles on everything like grief. It's nestled in the belly of the Midwest, a pale shadow cast long by the city's sprawls. My street, on the east side, is where the light fades first. Houses lean against each other, their paint peeled like sunburn, their yards choked with weeds that claw at the cracked pavement.  Folks here are mostly hard-worn, hands calloused from years of trying to make a go of it. They wave when you pass, their smiles weary but genuine. There's a quiet danger here, a stillness that hums with unspoken stories. 

A few years back, a boy, barely older than a pup, got caught in the crossfire outside a bar down the road. Our neighbors, they lost their son that night. The echo of that grief still hangs heavy in the air. We've been spared the worst, for now. A stolen lawn gnome here, a bike taken there, the usual brush with the shadows. But the darkness here is deeper, seeping from the ground like a slow poison. It's the kind of darkness that clings to your skin, whispers in your ear.

The opioid fog hangs over everything.  It's a cold wind that steals the breath from your lungs and leaves behind a hollow ache. Lives are lost, swallowed whole by that darkness. Yet, there's a flicker of light too.  

The schoolhouse, a beacon in the bleakness, is a place of warmth and hope. My son, he goes there, a flicker of light in his own right.  He's different, not quite whole, but the teachers, they see him, they nurture him. The schoolyard, it's a place of laughter and innocence, a fragile haven in a world gone mad. 

There are good folks here, fighting the good fight. They tend the wounded, they comfort the broken, they hold the line against the darkness. There's a stubborn hope that clings to this place, a belief that even in the deepest shadows, light can find a way to break through.

It's a town of contrasts, a tapestry woven with threads of despair and hope, of loss and resilience. It's a place I know, a place I love, flaws and all.

The city clung to the hill, buildings stacked like bone against the sky.  Each one a story, some whispered in silence, others etched in stone. Across the street, the old theater stood, a sentinel against the years, its marquee dark and silent. Down the way, a bar, a neon flicker in the dusk, drew in the restless souls with promises of cheap beer and worn amusement. The Hill, they called it, and it held its breath in the noonday sun, waiting for the shadows to lengthen.  

I lived in a tower of brick and steel, seven stories high, gazing out at the lives unfolding below. A park, a green lung in the concrete city, lay just a few blocks away. Encased in a ring of stone steps, it became a winter refuge for those who had nowhere else to go.  The rain, a relentless visitor in the cold months, turned the park into a canvas of puddles and mud, where tents huddled close, seeking warmth in shared misery.  They were a presence you couldn't ignore, a reminder of the city's hidden wounds.

But the beauty of Hilltop wasn't in its grand facades or its faded glory.  It was in the people, their stories etched in the lines on their faces, in the way they carried themselves.  This was a place that wore its past like a scar, a place where the whispers of violence still lingered in the alleyways.  The Hill, they said, had been a kingmaker and a graveyard, and the ghosts of its history still walked among them.

They spoke of the federal men, the DEA, who had come with their badges and their promises, trying to sweep away the darkness that had taken root. But the Hill had a way of holding onto its secrets, its scars.

The people here, they knew the stories. They knew the price of survival in a world that had forgotten them.  But they held onto their humanity, their hope, with a fierce tenacity. They looked out for each other, shared what little they had, and kept the flame of their community burning.  

I see it in the way the laundromat owner keeps the door open a little longer for a weary soul, in the way a stranger offers a jacket on a cold night.  In the eyes of a child, playing in the street, oblivious to the shadows that dance at the edges of their world.  Hilltop isn't perfect, but it has a heart, a pulse that beats beneath the surface of its history. It's a place where you can feel the weight of the past, but also the possibility of redemption.

This is where I belong, where I find myself, a stranger who has become a part of the tapestry.  The Hilltop is home, a place where the walls whisper stories, and the people teach you to listen.

The air hung thick and still over the fields, a silence broken only by the rustle of cornstalks in the wind. The houses huddled together, a patchwork of weathered siding and chipped paint, a testament to years of sun and storm. They weren't grand, not like the picture-book towns you see in magazines, but they were sturdy, built solid with hands calloused from honest work. Basements ran deep, cool and dark beneath the earth. Yards stretched out, uneven and overgrown in places, but always with the promise of a swing set swaying in the breeze or a garden bursting with life.  

Here, the people were the heart of the place. They didn't speak in a language of fancy words, but in the quiet understanding of shared experience. They watched out for each other, their lives intertwined like the roots of the ancient oaks that lined the main street.  

Kids rode bikes, their laughter echoing down the quiet lanes.  Dogs barked greetings at passersby. A screen door slammed shut, a reminder of simpler times.  There was a rhythm here, a heartbeat slow and steady as the waves lapping against the shores of the great lakes. 

This wasn't a place for anonymity. You knew your neighbor's name, their children's names, the story behind the chipped paint on their porch. This was a place where the sheriff knew your face and the ice cream man waved from his truck. And when the sun dipped low, casting long shadows across the fields, you felt a sense of peace settle over you, a knowing that you were home.

original_texts:
Since I live in a large city, my neighborhood is extremely diverse. Residential areas are dispersed, seemingly randomly, between commercial areas, where a variety of businesses are run. Some of these businesses are made up of offices, while others are various stores, restaurants, and places of entertainment. There is no shortage of new restaurants to eat at, or stores to shop in. While some stores are large, well-known, brands that are owned by large corporations, small boutiques are also increasingly popular. They are not only located in various malls, but they also line the streets, which are often in walking distance of neighborhoods that would otherwise be quiet and serene, if not surrounded by so many points of interest. There are also a couple of nearby parks, and I have noticed that people frequent these parks with their young children. Speaking of the people, thereâ€™s actually quite a bit of diversity within my neighborhood. In one small location, we have a prominent LGBTQ+ community, an Orthodox Jewish community, and a collection of refugees and immigrants from the former Soviet Union. Spanning a little further outside of my neighborhood, there are many more individuals of various races and origins, although they are sometimes broken up into their own little communities within the city. We have locations known as Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, and many more, which are only a few miles away. However, only a few miles can prove to be a very lengthy drive. Driving a distance of only 10 miles can sometimes span two hours, due to traffic, especially during rush hour. Hardly anyone in my city walks anywhere, though. While certain locations of interest are inevitably close-by, the city is huge, and people do not generally prefer to commute on foot. As a result, we also have some of the worst traffic in the world, and it can be difficult to find parking spots just about anywhere. Ironically enough, there has been a great deal of construction in recent years, as large apartment buildings are being added to the city. It is seems to be a popular destination, but many residents are disappointed by the prospect of even more people moving in, and even more vehicles on the roads. There are many different types of houses in my city, however. Not everyone lives, or wishes to live, in a large apartment building. Residential areas are made up of houses, of various sizes, and smaller apartment buildings and condominiums. Some properties contain single-family homes, while others contain duplexes. This is true even within my immediately neighborhood, so there is also no lack of diversity in regards to housing options. Similarly, the neighborhood is made up of people of varying ages, and to be perfectly honest, I am not familiar with the majority of my neighbors. It is not really a tight-knit community these days, although I have many memories from my childhood of playing outside with my next-door neighbor, and a few other friends from the neighborhood, who were all close to my age.
My neighborhood is interesting. Most of the houses are single family, but there are a few homes that have been split into two, while still being attached, if that makes much sense. My home has a small yard in front of it and a small driveway to the left of the house. It, like most of the others, reminds you of a time not so long ago where living in the suburbs was the American dream. This dream at once seemed to embrace the people of this country, but now its pulling away. But my neighborhood and many more still remain, still call out to us and those who visit that the dream is still alive, and we are still holding onto it as best we can. The people don't feel as optomistic as they used to, the upkeep of the little yards are not what they used to be, but there is still a car or two in every driveway, still the youth play as if the world around them was the whole of their existence. The public school that has been here for almost 90 years still stands, still seems conjure a future in today's youth, while stirring up nostalgia in the older residents. The churches are few and far between, mostly empty, but the basketball courts are still full. All of the homes look different, but feel the same. There is a large supermarket called super "A" that has been owned by a large Yemni family, who are quite possible the only Arab family in the neighborhood. The vast majority of the residents are African American. The streets are wide and the kids usually play footbal, only stopping to allow the cars to pass. Most of the people in my neighborhood have been here for generations and most can tell stories of a past where everyone knew everyone. There was a karate school, but when hollywood stopped making karate kid movies, the kids stopped wanting to be the karate kid, so its now a pharmacy, because drugs make everything better, or so I've heard. There is also a small movie theatre that plays old movies at a discounted price, spared from the crowds by the youth's disdane for its lack of just release titles, but favored by the elders, who think it is a small price to pay for a night out, without the kids of course. There is a single expressway that passes through my town. Though the exit and entrance are in the town next to ours. There was once a petition to get and exit for our town. The youth supported it, while the elders refused. It seems that having the expressway in our town would ruin it, so said the elders who eventually persuaded the city council to deny the request. They are building a new highschool, and we are trying to decide on a mascott for our town. I think a cyborg with a country accent and a log cabin would be then best representation of my town.
You might pass it up on first glance - after all, it is a residential area behind a shopping strip, not a place one would assume there are places to live. At least, not places most people would want to live. But if you go behind the old, abandoned Whole Foods and walk back behind the hotels which are only occupied annually aside from a few stints in the summertime for family reunions, you'll find an entire bustling community. Within these communities, on these streets, are a handful of apartment complex - situated next to each other carefully like Russian nesting dolls that have been scrupulously, carefully taken apart and set beside each other in a line down the road, piecemeal. The first apartments you come upon are ones which have been on the news for some fairly unsavory dealings, so we won't focus on those too much - appearances, after all, can be deceiving. But the apartments beside that complex, and the two complexes beside that one, are a whole other world that almost no one living in this area knows about. Across from those complexes is a community college's satellite campus - a quiet, sleepy set of buildings standing sentinel beside the road, where students putter in with coffee in hand, yawning at 7 in the morning to begin their sleepy days. The iron gates creak open to admit them one by one, while commuters shake their fists out the window and groan at them for holding up traffic on days attendance is higher. The road t-bones into another residential road, with a park on one side and a rehabilitation center for people who have broken bones in unfortunate circumstances. The treatment center boasts cheerful porch furniture, and a lazily undulating ceiling fan which churns the warm, thick summertime air back and forth. Children run back and forth in the grass at the park across the street, cartwheeling and pinwheeling across the prickly green stalks while bees lazily turn in the flower patches by the road. Old retired folks walk their dogs on the walking path, scowling at the teenagers on their skateboards and nodding demurely at the teenage girls clustered by the playground equipment, gossiping about boys and the latest YouTube sensations. There is a sushi place in a strip mall beside the park that has inexpensive food but never seems too busy - a swimming supply store right beside that, and a nail salon nestled in between. You could fill your pool for the season while getting a manicure and eating hibachi chicken, all at once - the beauty of a strip mall. There is a frozen yogurt place there too, one of the DIY kind, and you often see the teens in the park clutching cold, sweating cups of frozen yogurt covered in toppings while they do stunts on their skateboards and vape because they believe it to be the coolest. The neighborhood in question is a slice of Americana - a piece of history in the sleepy south where hardly anything changes, not even time.
“Where is everything?” she asked as we drove past the corn fields which filled the horizon. “This is it!” I said, knowing she’d be in shock of the sparseness of the open landscape. She was from a town in which the grocery store was a 5 minute walk from her house--she’d never seen this much open space in her life. Taken back by the ubiquity of corn fields, I shared with her what it was like to grow up in rural Ohio, and in that moment, she finally knew who I was and where I came from. Driving down a two-lane country road, you will reach a quarry which is filled with water. Just past it is the small development I live in. The houses are mostly composed of brick and stucco. All the houses have at least a half an acre of land to themselves which everyone takes pride in maintaining. During springtime, annually planted flowers are abundant along with the midwestern trees that change with every season. The driveways are all filled with the highest end Mercedes Benz luxury cars that glisten in the midday sun after a good, old-fashioned car wash. Continuing along the road toward my grey stucco home, my Korean neighbor is always outside with a friendly face. He tends to spend the entire day mowing his lawn and can be heard singing over his mower’s hum. Everyone in the neighborhood gets a laugh out of him, but he is always genuine and an amazing person with a unique history. He has grown older and has lost some of his wit as he aged. In his past he was a doctor and usually blends in with the grass and his John Deer Zero Turn mower. Finally, you will reach my home. In the side yard, geese are abundant and are chased by our Terrier. Out back, there is a small stream that feeds into the quarry. Here, you can hear bullfrogs, the stream, and the occasional “moo” from the nearby farms. Across the handmade wooden bridge is an untouched oasis filled with naturally growing trees, herbs, and wildflowers. Here was where I spent most of my childhood. From building tree forts to ‘hunting’ animals (which mostly consisted of chasing them), there was always something to do and usually a neighborhood child available for friendship. The winters in my small town can be painfully brutal, yet there is nothing more beautiful. The yard transforms from a sea of green into an empty wilderness. The trees that once housed vibrant pink, purple, and orange flowers turn into barren skeletons of bark. When blessed with the occasional snowfall, a winter wonderland appears overnight. The backyard is lined with snow angels made by my little sister, and snowmen. My sister and I fought frequently as kids, and during the winter, snowballs were our weapon of choice. We’d build massive igloo-like forts to house our weapons, usually with branches, like an arsenal. In our own little wonderland was where we played pretend during a time where nothing else mattered. We were just young kids without a care in the world.
The first thing you have to understand about Portland, Oregon is the definition of "weird". The unofficial town slogan, on the back of a building that serves as a pizza joint, bar, music venue, strip club, and skirts the law on at least half of these endeavors, is "Keep Portland Weird". To some, this is a small cry to remember the Portland of the 90's and early 2000's, a Portland that was less known and less expensive, generating creative and unique subcultures. To others, it is a beckoning call - come to Portland, where people will still call you weird, but as a compliment this time. Despite the influx of affluent Californians and the constant construction of condominiums to house these Californians, Portland is still weird. Weird does not mean always accepting, but it does mean accepting of things that are normally not accepted. Weird does not mean we do not have modern conveniences and modern fights. Like the rest of the country, we buy most of our things from China. There are a million ways of being weird, of being not normal, but Portland has plenty of normal. Portland has yoga and hipsters and business professionals. Perhaps weird means we just take all of this less seriously. In my neighborhood, as in many Portland neighborhoods, we have colorful houses, home gardens with flowers and herbs and vegetables lining the streets, and free boxes in the summertime. Free boxes are traditionally cardboard boxes containing items someone is getting rid of, but they can be plastic bags or boxes. They contain something magical, a treasure just perfect for the person wandering by, a surprising amount of the time. Free boxes tend to have clothes and books, but they can have anything. The magical potential of walking through a Southeast Portland neighborhood is what Portland is all about. That is, what Portland is all about to me, but I am just one variety of weird among thousands. Some people I live among would never dream of picking their clothes out of a box on the sidewalk. Those people go to goat yoga (yes, yoga with real live goats) or Timbers matches (the city's soccer team). Portland is full of people who love all sorts of things. Portland is full of people who pursue our dreams, or dream about pursuing our dreams while spending too much time at the bar. Yes, Portland has a drug problem. Drug problems tend to be (at their root) mental health problems, and the constant rain through much of the year, plus the dreary clouds, appear to be a contributor. Portland has a homelessness problem too, which no one seems to know what to do with. The homeless population is drawn by the social services Portland offers, better than in most parts of the country, but our services are insufficient, as in all parts of the country. The non-homeless population wavers between care and hatred. In this, we are not weird at all.
The mountains are always there. In the north, bearing witness to the sun’s journey every dawn and every dusk. No matter how much I forget about them or how caught up with work and life I am to notice, they are there, unwavering, unopposed, and unphased by life’s tribulations. Then on days when I am the most stressed and wound, they demand to be seen, and when I turn to them they let me rest my anxious soul, lending me some strength to go on, one day at a time. I first moved here when I started my undergrad, and the mountains to the north of campus where what first captivated me. Sure, the university has its own share of breathtaking sights in buildings and ponds and trees, which have their own share of my heart, but it’s the mountains that really holds its throne. The rest of the town is beautiful in its own right. There are countless cafés that were home to many hours of caffeine fueled cramming. One can walk or take the bus just a little further to the downtown area and be enveloped in an aura of antiquity by the faded colored bricks that line restaurants and office buildings. It is here that this seemingly suburban town shows as much bustle and vigor as it’s neighboring urban city. This doesn’t last for many blocks though, as one can escape, once again, to the serene small town by passing the library. This dichotomy of atmospheres in such proximity truly give this city a wonderous vibe as if it was beckoning to be explored. With this, it is easy to create many a cherished memory, each in association with a certain part of town. Whether it is walking past the rusted swings in the park with friends after an all-nighter or running through the busy downtown to catch the movie in the fancy theater for which the university provided tickets. Alas, it is also home to many harsh memories, as all places are bound to be in life. The ponds, in particular, can be a rather fitting place for reflection as well as crying sessions at two in the morning in the middle of an existential crisis. The latter of which, I have more experience in. While watching the turtles and ducks and insects live out their lives, each with some contribution or role, I couldn’t help but wonder about my own sense of purpose as I struggled to navigate this mystery called life. So, I walked past the pond, and past the park and little houses that scream of suburbia, until I reached a main street. It was then that sun shined its brilliant rays atop the palm trees, painting the sky along the way, and as I looked up at the sunrise, I realized I was walking north. Sure enough, they were there, as they had always been. The sturdy overbearing mountains grazed the hazy blue and yellow sky more than any building in the horizon, and as if speaking without words, stirred in me my sense of perseverance.
If you are planning on visiting Bensonhurt, Brooklyn, you will not have a difficult time finding it! Public transportation is very accessible and is one of the most popular forms of transportation in New York City. Bensonhurt is a fairly urban neighborhood, so you will still feel as if you are in New York City. During your visit, be prepared to see the various Asian stores all around. Over the past two decades, Bensonhurt has received an influx of Asian inhabitants. Because of this, you will see an Asian-owned store at least every block as you are walking. Most popular are supermarkets and laundromats. Coincidentally, these businesses are very popular among local residents, as quality of food in the supermarkets are superb, the prices are much cheaper, and finally yet importantly, it is very convenient. Just nearby where I am, there are four Asian supermarkets within two minutes of walking distance from each other. This just adds to the convenience of accessing grocery. I’m not saying Bensonhurst is purely populated by Asian inhabitants, though. It is quite diverse all around, with immigrants and their first-generation and second-generation American children here. Most of the large and popular businesses in the local area are Asian owned. In addition to these Asian owned businesses, there is also a recently renovated park nearby, which has around ten basketball courts, a large field for soccer or baseball, four handball courts, swings, a playground for kids, and even a water fountain for kids to enjoy water in the summer. Since we are in New York City, of course the parks are very diverse. You will see all sorts of diversity here, able to play and get along well. In this neighborhood, there aren’t many large corporate buildings. The only buildings you’d find are ones for co-op living, or condominium apartments. The majority of living spaces here are two-family houses though. Most of the people are quite nice, however, very noisy. Every day, you’d hear cars blasting their music as they drive by your house, or constantly flooring the gas on their cars which will wake you up in the morning. If you are planning on visiting during night time, you should be on your guard. This neighborhood is fairly safe, but people are unpredictable. You may run into people who want to start trouble for no reason, bullies and thieves. I myself have been bullied in this neighborhood in the past via physical assault, but this was many years ago. Another recent incident involved package stealing. Although a common thing, there are package thieves in this neighborhood. Last but not least, although New York City has a fine for people not cleaning up after their dogs, people don’t follow the rules here. Every morning, you will see at least one dog waste on your way to the train station, or on your way to the supermarket. My biggest pet peeve is dog waste on the floor everywhere I go in this neighborhood. Be careful and keep your shoes clean!
There aren't many sidewalks where I live. Everything seems to flow downward, and my house sits right at the crest of the steepest hill in the neighborhood. People call it the "work out hill" because so many joggers like to run up it during their daily work out. As there aren't any sidewalks at all on my street everyone walks on the road. There road is pitted in a few places and can feel a bit hazardous to drive on. Some of the telephone and electric wires strung up around the block at tattered looking. It rains and storms a lot in our area, so branches and other debris often strike down the power lines and the constant repairs make them look checkered and patchwork-y. There's many tall evergreen trees all around everywhere you look. But people here hate the trees. They strive to cut down as many as possible because the trees obstruct the view of the ocean. That's why many of the houses are built so high up on the hill, with huge glass-fronted second stories that loom up one after the other to take in the view of the bay. It's gorgeous around sunset when the water seems to get lit up from below and the sky turns orange. It's cloudy more often than not, though, so you end up seeing most of the sunlight through a haze. Most days are overcast and damp. Moss grows on everything it can: roofs, cars, and railings. I once left my car parked out in my driveway for a month and when I went out to use it, it had turned green and furry with moss. Took me three hours to scrap it all off. There aren't that many children around where I live, though there's a school only a few blocks away. Most of the people in my neighborhood are older, many of them retired. Instead of kids, people have dogs. It's common to see them sitting out in people's lawns or racing down the street after each other. If you leave a door or window open you risk having them sneak into your house. I found one once in my living room and had to shoo it back out the front door. Rabbits run wild around the area. Some of them are good sized, and the gardeners hate them because the dig up the roots of plants and burrow into people's lawns. My cats love them though, and have hunted most of them out of our neighborhood. We also get the usual assortment of birds: small sparrows and hummingbirds, and the occasional hawk or eagle sometimes swoops by until the neighborhood crows chase it off. There aren't any stores around, but if you hike downhill to the waterfront there's a few restaurants that serve fresh seafood. There isn't much of a beach down there, but the rocks along the shore are fun to hurl into the water. The bay itself isn't very wide. You can see the opposite shoreline clearly even through the mist on most days.
I live in a typical suburb area in a small southern town in Tennessee. It's a connecting street between two state highways, so we get a bit more traffic on the street than I'd like, but other than that, it's a quiet neighborhood. There's not too many folks that move in and out, so I've grown used to most of the people that live in the neighborhood. People busy themselves with yard work and other daily chores for the most part. In the winter, we sled down a hill on our side street. We live in a house at the front corner of our street, so we see everyone coming and going all day long and are familiar with the cars that people drive around here. Whenever we see a strange vehicle, we tend to take note of it. Some of the neighbors go walking for exercise or just to walk their dogs. Kids play on their bikes and all that you would expect from that. We are at home a lot since we work from our house. There are four of us, Myself and my Wife, and two Daughters ages eleven and fourteen. So, I'd say that everyone else is used to us coming and going as well. We get outside and play, sometimes even in the rain. Once in a while we grill outside on our back deck and it's always a pleasant smell from the barbecue and all. It seems that there's always someone cutting grass around here and you can hear a lawn mower nearly every day from March through about October, when the grass finally stops growing. We have a lot of trees in our neighborhood as it was originally a wooded area, so there's lots of shade, but there's always a lot of leaves in the Fall as well. So, that means raking and burning the leaves on a yearly basis. I like the smell of burning leaves too, so that's always a nice sign that Fall has arrived. Lately, we've not been having much Winter to speak of, so it just feels like a long Fall. Our garage is at the back of our house, so we seldom use the front door of our house unless someone knocks on the door, which is rare. I like to work in the garage on my truck or other projects from time to time and when I have the garage doors open, it feels like I'm more tuned into the neighborhood. On holidays it is pretty quiet around here. Thanksgiving sees some of the neighborhood families visiting with people from out of town and there are extra cars parked everywhere during that time of year. It's the same at other holidays like Mother's day and Christmas. All in all, I like living here. If it weren't a through street, it would be perfect.
My neighborhood is in the smack middle of the high desert, where there is dirt, dirt and more dirt. Unless someone has actually experienced living here, they probably donâ€™t really understand the feeling of always seeing brown , and when you do see a lawn, you know that person is spending a fortune on lawn care. When I first lived here in the 90s, houses were spread out far and wide. Now it is pretty much the same way by there are a lot of new additions. Honestly this place looks more and more like a city everyday, but supposed most places are changing the same way. Most of the time the people are very friendly, but just like any city you have your good parts and bad. In my neighborhood I'm surrounded by friendly old people iI guess it's a nicer neighborhood. The stores in this place are pretty much the store who have chains, like food for less and smart and final. If you want uscale you have to travel I never really see any whole foods or stores of that nature. The jobs that are most prominent in my city I would say not based on any official demographics, is construction. I think this is on account of this city is still not very developed, there is still a lot of wide open spaces to build. That kind of scares me, I like things the way they are now. I left a big city and I'm not keen on going back. Speaking of construction this was the field my full time job is located in, i am a drywall and T-bar instalator. What I like about my home is the different animals. People come to the high desert for many reasons, not the least of which is the stark beauty of the desert itself. High desert climate and topography have created challenging ecosystems which need protecting and which are home to different types of wildlife. Human residents of the high desert should take the time to learn about the non-human residents who share this environment in order to co-exist safely and harmoniously. My family and I have adapted very well to the wildlife. I have three children and they are all obsessed with lizards and dessert bugs, as I am writing this now they are outside trying to catch different specimens. As far as attractions goes we have some. Additionally, Victorville is a good place for families to experience the desert. It can generate a different experience. If you can, plan your visit to coincide with its annual event: the San Bernardino County Fair. The fair will enrich your visit with the right mix of activities and fun the Victorville way. Pop by the nearby Wrightwood to see the snow covered mountains and take some winter sports lessons to finish out your visit. Interested in the natural history and culture of the high desert ecosystem? The Victor Valley Museum includes geological and paleontological specimens, Native American artifacts, and historical objects that tell the story of the development of society and industry of Victorville.
When asked to describe my neighborhood, I'm sure that my answer is somewhat unique. While others who respond to this are most likely homeowners with their own individual lives, my situation is a tad bit different. I consider my neighborhood to be the college campus that I stay on, and the people that live in my dormitory to be my community. I also consider the surrounding campus to be my neighborhood, albeit to a lesser extent. Despite this peculiarity, my neighborhood shares some commonalities with the more conventional ideas about a neighborhood. Just like any conventional neighborhood, the neighborhood I stay in has houses, people, stores and parks. Let us begin by discussing the "houses" that comprise my neighborhood. Before I begin to explore the houses in my neighborhood, it would be best to clarify the types of house that can be found in my neighborhood. There are three types of housing in my immediate vicinity, the apartments, the actual houses, and the dormitory houses. First, In the apartments, there are usually between 2-4 people in any given room, and there are about 4-6 rooms on each floor. The most common building type can house about 2 floors, so on average, there are 20 or so people living in each building. Second, are the actual houses that are available for anyone with an affiliation to the school to rent. Typically these are 2-4 bedroom setups that usually have alumni living in them.
